title: Did The High Court Just Pick Sides In the T-Series vs PewDiePie War, Banning Diss Tracks?
text:
If Indian corporations had a rap battle, it would start with “Who are you even?” proceed to the “You don’t know who I am!” stage and end with a “Hindi Mein Bol! Tu Roadie Banega?” Every time they argue online, it eventually boils down to calling a ban and basically, some of us simply cannot take trash talk. If a certain YouTube celebrity went into a trash talk battle, he starts out acting like he doesn’t care and then drop all the clues of caring way too much, enough to make you care too. This is precisely what went down between T-Series and PewDiePie. The weeks-long rivalry for most subscribers on YouTube came to a close call several times during which they had quite a few run-ins. Just when T-Series was on a winning streak, earlier this month, overtaking PewDiePie, he took digs at the caste system in a video titled ‘Congratulations’ (don’t try googling it). Too bad it you haven't already watched it because if you try now, this is what you'll see:
The video featured PewDiePie being quite a sore loser. But, we guess T-Series wanted to win that race too. T-Series not only deployed a hoard of Indians (read: I’m not kidding, they made celebrities appeal to the masses) to take PewDiePie down. You can make India win! It’s so exciting to know that @Tseries, is on the brink of becoming the biggest YouTube channel in the world! Good luck @itsBhushanKumar! Let’s all subscribe to ensure #BharatWinsYouTube pic.twitter.com/um8cmiWcUr — Varun ZAFAR Dhawan (@Varun_dvn) March 7, 2019
Taking it to a whole new level appealed to the law after facing some serious humiliation at the hands of the YouTube content creator. The Delhi High Court issued an order to take down the diss tracks “Congratulations” on T-Series’ and “Bitch lasagna”. In Congratulations, he blatantly claimed the music label puts out pirated music amongst other defamatory remarks. The High Court, stated abusive, vulgar and racist comments as the reason for the legal move. The verdict, however, isn’t out. There’s going to be another hearing July. Till then, the diss tracks will still be unavailable for Indian viewers.
summary: Most "sore loser" on YouTube is the new battle!
label: human

title: Did The High Court Just Pick Sides In the T-Series vs PewDiePie War, Banning Diss Tracks?
text:
See also: T-Series and Heineken must stop using 'bitches' for advertising because it's 'blasphemous'
The High Court, seeking a statement from the High Court against the content of these advertisements, issued several proceedings and sought detailed responses from the various parties. If Indian corporations had a rap battle, it would start with “Who are you even?” proceed to the “You don’t know who I am!” stage and end with a “Hindi Mein Bol! Tu Roadie Banega?” Every time they argue online, it eventually boils down to calling a ban and basically, some of us simply cannot take trash talk. A decision on the whole order is scheduled to be handed down by the Supreme Court in May 2019. If a certain YouTube celebrity went into a trash talk battle, he starts out acting like he doesn’t care and then drop all the clues of caring way too much, enough to make you care too. Based on responses received by the High Court, the High Court issued several proceedings with three days period for all the submissions and issues raised. This is precisely what went down between T-Series and PewDiePie. The weeks-long rivalry for most subscribers on YouTube came to a close call several times during which they had quite a few run-ins. Just when T-Series was on a winning streak, earlier this month, overtaking PewDiePie, he took digs at the caste system in a video titled ‘Congratulations’ (don’t try googling it). The High Court declined to hear the matter after receiving the responses but only referred the matter to its Appellate division. Too bad it you haven't already watched it because if you try now, this is what you'll see:
The video featured PewDiePie being quite a sore loser. But, we guess T-Series wanted to win that race too. In December, after a recent court application by the managing director of The High Court, Bob Zwirner, at the supreme court, the Supreme Court’s order said that the court will not interfere with the firm’s recommendations. Further, the court stated that this information must be available for public scrutiny. T-Series not only deployed a hoard of Indians (read: I’m not kidding, they made celebrities appeal to the masses) to take PewDiePie down. You can make India win! Twitter-owned firm, YouTube has been announced as an associate counsel for this matter. It’s so exciting to know that @Tseries, is on the brink of becoming the biggest YouTube channel in the world! Good luck @itsBhushanKumar! Let’s all subscribe to ensure #BharatWinsYouTube pic.twitter.com/um8cmiWcUr — Varun ZAFAR Dhawan (@Varun_dvn) March 7, 2019
Taking it to a whole new level appealed to the law after facing some serious humiliation at the hands of the YouTube content creator. The High Court first began hearing the evidence from the audio production companies, VH1 and Scream Factory. The Delhi High Court issued an order to take down the diss tracks “Congratulations” on T-Series’ and “Bitch lasagna”. In Congratulations, he blatantly claimed the music label puts out pirated music amongst other defamatory remarks. The High Court, stated abusive, vulgar and racist comments as the reason for the legal move. The verdict, however, isn’t out. SAMA Entertainment will also represent The High Court. There’s going to be another hearing July. In its order, the High Court may declare certain elements of these advertisements illegal. Till then, the diss tracks will still be unavailable for Indian viewers. However, the advertisement sent out by The High Court should be considered in the context of the issues relating to parody and stereotype.
summary: Most "sore loser" on YouTube is the new battle!
label: human

The Delhi High Court issued an order to take down the diss tracks “Congratulations” on T-Series’ and “Bitch lasagna”. In its order, the High Court may declare certain elements of these advertisements illegal. In Congratulations, he blatantly claimed the music label puts out pirated music amongst other defamatory remarks. A decision on the whole order is scheduled to be handed down by the Supreme Court in May 2019. The High Court, stated abusive, vulgar and racist comments as the reason for the legal move. Till then, the diss tracks will still be unavailable for Indian viewers. See also: T-Series and Heineken must stop using 'bitches' for advertising because it's 'blasphemous'
The High Court, seeking a statement from the High Court against the content of these advertisements, issued several proceedings and sought detailed responses from the various parties. The High Court first began hearing the evidence from the audio production companies, VH1 and Scream Factory. Based on responses received by the High Court, the High Court issued several proceedings with three days period for all the submissions and issues raised. In December, after a recent court application by the managing director of The High Court, Bob Zwirner, at the supreme court, the Supreme Court’s order said that the court will not interfere with the firm’s recommendations.
summary: Most "sore loser" on YouTube is the new battle!
